column1: spoken_words
...and I know the little fellas would love romping around my many acres, chasing my many cars, drinking from my many toilets...
It's no use. I guess I'll have to leave all my money to the Egg Advisory Council. Eggs have gotten quite a bad rap lately, you know, Smithers.
Why that's a fabulous idea. Anything else you'd like? How about real lead in the radiation shields? Urinal cakes maybe? Smithers, throw this at him.
Rafting, eh? It's a perfect way to entertain them. Finally, humanity has found a use for water.
Cheating for me? Good lord, Smithers, that's patently unnecessary. I'm one of the world's finest golfers! In all the years you've caddied for me, I've never lost a-- Oh.
Yes, but I couldn't understand a word that man said. Misht Burnsh, dajna boo mafrn friszner... er hound-dog.
Smithers had thwarted my attempt to take candy from a baby, but with him out of the picture, I was free to wallow in my own crapulance.
Although this millennium is still young, I feel it is time to award this giant trophy paid for with your healthcare cuts...
He's got them eating out of his hand. And to think you doubted him, Smithers.
Ah. 206 bones... fifty miles of small intestine... full, pouting lips. Why, this fellow is less a snowman than a god.
Ah, Simpson, you big virile son-of-a- gun. How would you like a check for two-thousand dollars?
And what book is that? The Ape Who Wanted A Big Bonus? Stop wasting my time, you corn-fed man-cow.
Simpson, I don't know how you're doing it, but you're outputting ten times the power our American plant ever did.
I figured if one six-pack holder will catch one fish, a million sewn together will catch a million fish. Watch.
Oh yes. And this must be your lovely wife... ... "Marge." And look at little... ... "Lisa". Why, she's growing like a weed. And this must be... ... "Brat".
That's it. Frimble about with your widgets and doobobs. It'll all be a monument to futility when my plan comes to fruition.

Heh, heh. As well they might. You know, Smithers, when I was a young buck, my patented fadeaway pitch was compared by many to the "trouble ball" of the late great Satchel Paige. Spit on this for me, Smithers.
Call me old-fashioned, but movies were sexier when the actors kept their clothes on. Vilma Banky could do more for me with one raised eyebrow than an entire...
But I'll need someone to watch my house. Who's that fellow who always screws up and creates havoc?
I am only eighty-one. You may find this hard to believe... but in my salad days, my crowning glory was a bright shock of strawberry blond curls.
Listen, SeÃ±or Spielbergo. I want you to do for me what Spielberg did for Oskar Schindler.
At five-fifteen an hour, it would take an eternity to make my fortune back -- and FICA wasn't helping.
I see it all now! You're just a bunch of yesmen! I was making the wrong moves and you were too gutless to tell me. Isn't that right?

Think of the economy as a car and the rich man as the driver. If you don't give the driver all the money, he'll drive you over a cliff. It's just common sense. Furthermore, rich people feel things more deeply than the common man.
Heh, heh, heh. Heh, heh. Ohh, you'll find this amusing -- the suit Charlie Chaplin was buried in.
Her shapely gams have finally persuaded me to switch from the Julian calendar to the Gregorian!
Oh, for the love of Peter! That's all anybody brought. Some damn fool went around telling everyone I love that slimy goop. Well, toss it in the pile over there.
Now that you've all agreed to reap the windfall of my death, I must return to my large empty mansion to rattle around and await the inevitable... alone.
Uh, would it be all right if I kept this portrait? To remind me of better times?
Due to recent fluctuations in my judgment, and the once-in-a-lifetime mistake of trusting another human being, I am saddened to announce massive layoffs.
Well, now that I'm forcibly retired, I feel I should give back to society and do some charitable work. But first, I want to take a lot of opium.
Maybe the planet wants a strong man to take her by the hand and lead her!
...some can't even get a fair shake, or even a square deal... Ummmm, smells delightful.
Look at that Comic Book Fellow calmly eating candy like a Spaniard. Time for monkey to shine.
A man who provided the Burns Corporation with forty-five years of faithful service, Mr. Jack Marley.
Simpson, you can take your putrid mess far out of my sight, you songless land-whale!
Get going! And answer those phones, install a computer system, and rotate my office so the window faces the hills.
Oh well, there'll be plenty of time for explanations later. Right now, I'll be taking my puppies back.
After all these years, things are finally starting to go my way. I feel like celebrating. I...
Let's see, social security number... naught-naught-naught, naught-naught, naught-naught-naught-two. Damn Roosevelt. Cause of parents' death... Got in my way.
The electric chair is on, eh? Then the old prison has been getting free electricity for thirty years. I'll put a stop to that.

Well, Countess Van Zeplin and I... What in blaze... Now you listen to me, you bargain basement Baudelaire. I'm not some dizzy starlet who can't string two words together. I can write this thing myself. You're fired.
My first dollar! Thanks to you, Lisa, and our hemp-smoking friend. Shine on, you crazy diamond.
That's the kind of man I need on my team, Smithers. A real scrapper. A self-made man like me. Bring this Grimes fellow to me. I want to make him my executive vice president.
Okay, let's make this sporting, Leonard. If you can tell me why I shouldn't fire you, without using the letter "E," you can keep your job.
Oh well, I used to rile the late, great Connie Mack with that one at old Shibe Park.
It's a remarkable thing. In the short time you were gone, I learned to be completely self reli--
Because of my svelte physique, I was able to fit in a narrow air pocket.

My older brother was trampled by a horse, my sister died of a poisoned potato, my twin was shot, that girl was stabbed, he ate another poisoned potato, spontaneous combustion, fell down a well, potato, potato, and impaled on the Chrysler Building.
Oh, by the way, you new fellows, there's a sign up sheet for the company softball team on the bulletin board over there. Eh, just in case you wish to play.
Well, it looks like you've made a new fan. It'd be a shame to let him down...
No. It's better that they hear it from me. I'll tell them the truth in the simplest way I know how.
Not exactly. Smithers, for attempting to kill me, I'm giving you a five percent pay cut.
What makes a man endanger his job, and yes, even his life, by asking me for money?
Please, Abe, let me buy you dinner in exchange for a few tales of the golden age of professional grappling.
Oh yeah, settlement? Fine! Hang your heads in shame, you over-priced, under-brained, glorified notary publics! Just get that big ape to my house tonight and we'll buy him off with a banana or two.
You know, lighthearted. Fancy free. "Mothers lock up your daughters, Smithers is on the town!"
So ironic. After all my years of stock jobbing, gun running, attempted murder, successful murder, and tom peepery, they get me on a petty multi-million dollar art theft.
Try to take my eggs will you? Well, this rooster has a beak! A beak which calls out death-a-doodle-doo!
Simpson, I worked here for three-score and twain. That's sixty-two years in the "New English". Now, come with me, I want to show you something.
I dreamed about her again last night, Smithers. You know that dream where you're in bed and they fly in through the window?
Well, you've won this round Simpson, but I'll grind you into the earth like a bug!
This entire plant is in his name -- so when they come to put C. M. Burns in jail, it's the canary that does the time.
And to think, Smithers -- you laughed when I bought Ticketmaster. "Nobody's going to pay a 100% service charge."
I suppose that's normal background radiation? The kind you would find in any well-maintained nuclear facility? Or, for that matter, playgrounds and hospitals.
Okay, it's time to win the love of these hateful morons. Step one: amass a vast media empire.
You're right. We're getting screwed! There must be something I can do about this. Wait! Yes! I think I know just the thing!
If you hand over the concert hall to me, I'll assume the debt and all of your problems will disappear.
Workers, please! There'll be time for the frozen pudding wagon later! You still owe me ten more Iroquois twists!
Well, that broke the ice. Now, any man who lives till noon tomorrow shall win his freedom.
Hello. My name is Mr. Snrub, and I come from... eh, someplace far away. Yes, that will do. Anyway, I-I say we invest that money back in the nuclear plant.
Oh, don't congratulate me, congratulate Bay State Fish Sticks... as my advisor, you're entitled to ten percent of the proceeds.

Well I'll make these rioters regret their folly. This prison will make Abu Ghraib look like the Four Seasons. Smithers, we'll need electrical wire, a hood and someone who can really point at genitalia.
Snappy, do you it's hard to imagine, but I was once a barefoot boy with cheek of tan. I dreamed of grand slam homeruns and wiping out nations with the stroke of a pen.
Smithers, years ago, I blew the chance to buy Picasso's "Guernica" for a song. Luckily, that song was "White Christmas," and by hanging onto it, I made billions.
All right, let's cut to the chase. My board has given me permission to go up to... twelve goats.

All right, everyone. It's time for your Christmas "boni." Everyone gets a five dollar cafeteria voucher...and for your boy, a confectioner's card featuring a current baseballer. It's that rookie from the New York Nine.
That intrepid lad is my great grandfather! Franklin Jefferson Burns. Tossing that tea without a care for what the caffeine would do to the Fenway Flounder.
Smithers, I'm a proud fellow, and it's not easy for me to admit defeat. But I know just the thing to make me feel better -- shopping!
Yes, well, to have a successful baseball club, you need teamwork. Not some hot dog admissions officer playing by his own rules.
So, let's see how my burly-bottomed ball-handlers are faring. Smithers, we're leading two to nothing! Run out the clock, boys. Run out the clock...
Welcome to the American dream: a billionaire using public funds to construct a private playground for the rich and powerful.
Now there's nothing to do now but sit back and wait for the kudos to roll in.
The Springfield Opera House, of which I am founder, artistic director, and standing ovation starter, is producing La BohÃ¨me. I want you to sing the lead.
In closing, gentle reader, I'd like to thank you. What's that you say? Me thanking you? No, it's not a misprint. For you see, I enjoyed writing this book as much as you enjoyed reading it. The end.
Well, I won't go without a fight, wink, wink. Heh. Let me show you around.
This is a thousand monkeys working at a thousand typewriters. Soon they'll have written the greatest novel known to man.

And we've got to change our approach to immigration. I have a progressive proposal to let into this country, two hundred grimy Irishmen a year. I've got lots of potatoes that need peeling and stables to be mucked out.
"Thank you all so much. I love Springfield, from the cuddliest infant to th... ... puppies... patriotism... bluebirds..." I'm not reading this drivel. This speech is over.
Good Lord! That canary was supposed to be my pigeon. I need to find a patsy quick!
Well, I... you see... it's just is it a crime to want nice things? And then to steal them from a public museum where any gum-chewing monkey in a Tufts University jacket can gawk at them? I think not!
Would you like to be the first to take a tour of the plant, Li'l Lisa?
Yes, thank you, Kent. Fifteen minutes from now I will wreak a terrible vengeance on this city. No one will be spared. No one!
Mattingly, I thought I told you to trim those sideburns. Go home! You're off the team! For good!
Very well, you had your chance. I'm going to shred you like a Christmas card! Now, get out.
Oh cut the false modesty, it's getting tiresome. Besides, it's your duty. Employee of the Month isn't all ham and plaques.
If it makes you feel worse, I'm the man who bought the stock you sold.
Mr. Simpson, I dread the day when a hundred thousand dollars isn't worth groveling for.
I am pleased to dedicate this remote work terminal. It will allow our safety inspector here to perform his duties from home. And so, excelsior to you, Mr. What's the name of this gastropod?
It looked a lot better in my memory. But do you know what, Smithers? I will find Lilah and win her back... I'll just check with the old gang. Hemingway!
